awd_titl_txt: Phase I I/UCRC Arizona State University Site: Center for Efficient Vehicles and Sustainable Transportation Systems (EV-STS).
awd_abstract_narration:
Phase I I/UCRC Arizona State University Site: Center for Efficient Vehicles and Sustainable Transportation Systems (EV-STS).

Arizona State University (ASU) will help establish and operate a multi-institution Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) for Efficient Vehicles and Sustainable Transportation Systems (EV-STS) as one of two charter sites (University of Louisville will host the other charter site). Such a center is needed to support the U.S. automotive/ground transportation industry?s efforts to meet demanding new federal regulations governing vehicle fuel economy and emissions, as well as society?s expectations for improved sustainability in economic and personal activities. The EV-STS center will engage the industry?s critical stakeholders - vehicle manufacturers, component and system suppliers, fleet operators, ground transportation industry infrastructure providers, and state and local governments - in identifying important efficiency/sustainability related problems, and formulating a research program that develops innovative solutions.


The mission of the EV-STS center and its ASU site is to leverage collaborations among corporate, government, and academic partners to conduct and disseminate industry-relevant research on technologies and tools that facilitate the design, manufacture, deployment, and operation of energy efficient, environmentally sustainable ground vehicles. The scope of this mission includes passenger cars, light- and heavy duty trucks, and motorized off-road equipment. It encompasses both vehicle-level technologies, and the infrastructure and transportation systems that incorporate ground vehicles. The mission is divided into four primary thrust areas: powertrains for full-electric vehicles and the entire continuum of electric-hybrid powertrains, including batteries, electric machines, power electronics, thermal management, packaging, etc., advanced internal combustion engines and alternative fuels, non-powertrain vehicle systems, and ground transportation systems and infrastructure. Within EV-STS the ASU site will have a research focus on realizing sustainable electrified vehicles. Site-specific topic areas are likely to include power electronics, power electronics device, system integration, and materials and processes for integration for vehicle-connected wearable health monitoring electronics for driver safety and overall transportation system safety.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: The NSF IUCRC for Efficient Vehicles and Sustainable Transportation Systems (EVSTS) was established in 2016 as a collaborative effort between Arizona State University (ASU), the University of Alabama (UA), the University of Louisville (UL), and the University of Texas at Austin (UT), to undertake industry-relevant research to yield transformational improvements in the energy efficiency and environmental sustainability of ground vehicles, specifically passenger cars, trucks, and motorized non-road equipment. Its research program encompasses vehicle-level technologies and transportation system infrastructure, reflecting the complexity and global nature of the automotive and ground transportation industries. In the pivotal five years since EVSTS was formed, the automotive industry weathered shifting political priorities about climate change and associated greenhouse gas emissions targets while working to comply with increased U.S. efficiency standards - all while balancing the complex economic realities of their businesses: How to achieve emissions reductions and efficiency improvements for internal-combustion engine (ICE) vehicles, which make up approximately 95% of global automotive sales [1], while positioning themselves for a future in electric power? During Phase I, EVSTS organized its program into five research thrust areas: 1) electrified vehicle powertrains, 2) conventional powertrains and alternative fuels, 3) non-powertrain vehicle systems optimization, 4) efficient/sustainable autonomous vehicles (AVs), and 5) transportation systems and infrastructure. It conducted fundamental, industry-relevant research with 29 projects funded by 25 companies and government agencies, involving 29 faculty, 10 undergraduates, 15 master’s students, 25 PhD students, and 5 post-docs.

 

Intellectual Merit: Achieving global environmental sustainability is a generational problem that represents perhaps the most critical technological challenge of our time. Electricity generation (31%) and the transportation sector (27%) are the largest contributors to U.S. greenhouse gas emissions. Wheeled ground vehicles are, in turn, the source of most of the transportation emissions and have an increasing impact on emissions from electricity generation. Solutions to the problem must address vehicle sustainability without unduly disrupting an industry that is central to the nation’s economic health and its citizens’ lifestyles. The EVSTS center Phase I research projects, carried out by center researchers along with industrial members,  provided solutions that include: 1) the development of magnetic materials, power electronic components, and permanent magnet motors, and battery-life control systems for electrified vehicle (EV) powertrains, 2) the improvement of engine mechanical and thermodynamic efficiency, high-pressure Diesel fuel systems, emissions- and powertrain-control systems, integrating conventional powertrains with launch-assist and idle-free operation technologies, 3) the development of lightweight structural materials, reduction of component friction, drag, rolling resistance, and thermal losses for non-powertrain vehicle systems, 4) the development of fifth- and sixth-generation (5G and 6G) telematics, sensors, and communication technologies; integration of AVs with existing ground transportation; and development of electromagnetic interference materials and antennas for sustainable AVs, and 5) the incorporation of ground vehicle efficiency/sustainability considerations into urban planning and decision-making, defining operational conditions impacting the deployment of energy efficient vehicles and transportation systems, implanting Internet of Things in vehicle to transportation infrastructure connections, and vehicle-grid interactions for transportation systems and infrastructure. These projects helped accelerate the electrification of ground vehicles, enhance the transportation infrastructure for autonomous vehicles, and help achieve greenhouse gas targets. 

 

Broader Impacts: In addition to research mission, EVSTS center has achieved goals to support the engagement of underrepresented groups in vehicle-related engineering and technology areas; to improve automotive industry education by creating new undergraduate and graduate courses in automotive area, engaged professional development, and workforce training; and in a way, increased the economic competitiveness of the United States in this critical industry. We are committed to the involvement of underrepresented minority students in this research program. During Phase I, these goals were met, for example, in the following ways: 1) engaging women faculty members as PIs/co-PIs, and 2) training both graduate and undergraduate students, including female students, via relevant research projects., and disseminated center research results through professional conferences presentation such as Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE), publications, and outreach activities, including public display of electric vehicles at the industrial advisory meetings.
